In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2011 country programming mission, the Government of the People's Republic 
of China (PRC) requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
for Developing a Legal System for the Credit Market.1  A reconnaissance mission was fielded on 
9 March 2011 and a fact-finding mission for the TA visited Beijing on 26–29 April 2011. An 
understanding  was  reached  on  the  objectives,  scope,  terms  of  reference,  cost  estimates, 
financing  plan,  and  implementation  arrangements  of  the  TA.2  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC's legal system has created a solid foundation for the operation of the financial 
market. This is impressive given the age of the legislation, much of which was first approved in 
the early 1990s. The recent plans to amend the General Rules of Lending, Rules of Deposit 
Insurance, Bankruptcy Law Ordinance on Bankruptcy of Financial Institutions, and others are 
examples of ongoing legal and regulatory development. The establishment of a multilevel credit 
market is a keystone of the PRC's financial market development and legal system reform. 
 
3.  The  2008  financial  crisis  encouraged  the  PRC's  regulators  to  consider  further  the 
importance of systemic security for the financial market. While the PRC’s financial system 
avoided direct negative impacts of the crisis, the lessons learned helped define flaws in the 
financial market environment. These weaknesses include the inadequacy of mechanisms for 
liquidation of insolvent or bankrupt financial institutions; and lack of clear definition, legitimacy of, 
and effective regulatory framework for the credit market. 
 
4.  Recognition of the legal status of the credit market and development of a suitable 
regulatory system has been an issue for many years. As a high-savings society, the PRC has 
significant amounts of funds seeking investment opportunities. Savers facing strict controls on 
interest rates seek alternatives to bank deposits, government and corporate bonds, and the 
vacillating values of equity markets. Restrictions in the structure of the credit market have 
contributed to the predominance of the state-owned banking system, which caters to large-scale 
state-owned enterprises. Without clearer legal definition and recognition of the credit market and 
provision of a broader range of credit services from a wide variety of financial institutions, such 
activities had to be largely carried out in the gray area between the approved pilot experiments 
of microcredit financing and illegal, Ponzi-type money pooling schemes. Despite the recent 
emergence  of  city  commercial  banks,  microcredit  companies,  village  banks,  and  other 
institutions, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and rural households still face severe 
constraints on credit access due to the lack of legal definition and rules on market conduct. 
 
5.  The PRC State Council and the People’s Bank of China (PBC) have paid close attention 
to  maintaining  financial  security  and  enhancing  the  credit  market.  Accordingly,  PBC  has 
developed regulations for deposit insurance, the exit of financial institutions from the market, 
and  macro-prudential  issues.  The  State  Council  and  PBC  have  modified,  enacted,  and 
published numerous regulations since 1996. Legal changes are generally based on the review 
of specially permitted experiments with financial products and services. Pilots are allowed, on a 
very small scale, to determine the usefulness of innovations before legal changes are made to 
allow their expansion. From 2005 to 2010 PBC, the China Banking Regulatory Commission, and

local governments provided numerous opportunities for experimentation with new institutional 
forms—such as microcredit companies and rural village banks—and with various types of credit 
services—such  as  microcredit,  group  guaranteed  credit,  and  cash  flow-based  loans.  The 
academic  community  and  research  institutions  have  been  carefully  considering  the 
effectiveness and results of these institutions and products. Researchers have demonstrated 
the effectiveness and improved outreach of pilot credit products and services to target groups. 
In particular, the pilot work has promoted the growth of SMEs and helped provide limited 
services to lower-income households in rural areas. 
 
6.  Certain problems do exist in the credit system as currently defined in the law, which the 
extensive pilot work has helped define. The PRC's credit-related legal system so far has been a 
transplant from external legal systems, which has created certain difficulties in interpretation and 
use. For example, the nature of credit is not defined, since the existing legislation has led to 
different interpretations of the legal definition of credit. In addition, it is unclear how credit should 
be regulated (and by which agency), how to ensure universal use of and information sharing by 
credit bureaus, how to regulate the secondary market for loan resales, what responsibilities 
exist for consumer protection, and how to handle over-indebtedness.  
 
7.  The next step in modernizing the legal structure is the establishment of a clear definition 
of formal credit and its operations in the market, as opposed to household members sharing 
funds or other informal financial arrangements that may not need regulation. In addition, setup 
of a tiered institutional structure for the PRC's credit market is important, so that institutions can 
transform and add services—with stronger regulation—as they grow. This requires revisions in 
the legal system governing credit delivery, repayment, and operations of credit providers. In 
addition,  a  fundamental  decision  must  be  made  on  whether  credit  will  be  regulated  by  a 
separate market-conduct regulator or added to the current responsibilities of PBC, the China 
Banking Regulatory Commission, and other regulators. If these steps are not taken, risks of 
increasing debt stress in certain segments of the market, suboptimal competition and potentially 
predatory  practices,  misallocation  of  credit  between  market  segments,  and  enforcement 
problems may emerge. 
 
8.  Prior  experience  in  legal  reform  and  drafting  in  the  PRC  is  instructive,  particularly 
scholarly assessments such as that of the 5-year legal drafting project financed by the United 
Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP),  which  assisted  the  development  of  22  priority 
financial  laws.  The  methodology  for  legal  development  involves  (i)  assessment  of  key 
international jurisdictions to determine which are most relevant; (ii) a focused study tour that 
looks closely at the context of relevant legislation and the positive and negative effects in 
selected countries, as well as implementation of the law; (iii) assessment of the specific issues 
in the PRC, analyzing what difficulty the new law is expected to address, the context and 
behaviors of various persons who engage with the issue (in this case, borrowers and lenders); 
alternative legal options with costs and benefits for the various market participants; and (iv) how 
the laws can best be implemented and adjusted as needs become known.3 
 
9.  In Premier Wen Jiabao’s presentation of the Twelfth Five Year Plan to the National 
People’s Congress on 7 March 2011, the seventh of the eight key areas was “Deepen Opening-
up Policy”. Specific steps under this area—which reinforce the importance of this TA—include: 
(i)  improve socialist democracy and the socialist legal system;

(ii)  accelerate the reforms of the fiscal, taxation, and financial systems; and

controllable. 
 
10.  The PRC’s Twelfth Five Year Plan outlines the strategy to develop an early warning and 
response  mechanism  for  financial  crises  and  to  specifically  improve  financial  legislation, 
including credit law. The Commercial Bank Law will be revised and new regulations such as 
deposit insurance rules and financial institution exit rules need to be developed to rectify certain 
systemic flaws and weaknesses in the financial market. This requires not only developing new 
laws, but also reviewing the existing laws and regulations on the issue. New laws as well as 
suggested amendments will create internal legal consistency and avoid conflict between laws. It 
also requires a careful assessment of the context of credit markets and the participants to 
determine  the  best  legal  mechanisms  for  good  market  behavior  and  the  development  of 
adequate institutions and rules. 
 
11.  The TA directly supports the process of enabling full legislation to facilitate expansion of 
piloted  institutional  and  product  innovations  in  the  credit  market  in  accordance  with  the 
approved plan. The PRC country partnership strategy 2008–20104 provides for support to a xiao 
kang society through inclusive growth and environmental sustainability.5 ADB has committed to 
six key areas of support. Governance engagement includes legal and regulatory reform, and the 
enabling environment for private sector reform includes finance sector reform. 
 
12.  The TA builds naturally on prior ADB work on legislation, which includes 26 TAs or 
project components for $13.3 million equivalent over the last 25 years. ADB’s Law and Policy 
Reform program in the PRC from 1993 to 2003 facilitated the development of commercial and 
economic laws. The work resulted in adoption of the Securities Law, Trust Law, Company Law 
(amendment), Bankruptcy Law, and legal adjustment relating to antidumping, countervailing 
duties, safeguards, import and export of goods, Foreign Trade Law, and cross-border merger 
and acquisition, upon accession to the World Trade Organization. Since 2003, ADB’s Law and 
Policy Reform has focused on competition policy and laws, development and reform of financial 
markets, including asset-based securitization, and development of the capital market.  
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The proposed impact of the TA is a legislative structure for a multi-tiered credit market 
consistent with international standards, adapted to the needs of the PRC—as shown in the 
passage, by the end of 2017, of legislation defining credit and governing key aspects of entry, 
operations, exit, and oversight of financial institutions delivering credit. The outcome is an 
established legal basis for credit definition, market entry, delivery, trade, and exit of financial 
institutions at the national and local government levels—as shown in the completion, by the end 
of  2013,  of  the  legal  framework  and  drafting  instructions  for  credit  services  and  related 
institutional arrangements.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  This policy and advisory TA will help modernize legislation that governs credit markets in 
the PRC by responsibly expanding access to credit services, particularly in rural areas and for

oversight, and exit, and develop drafting instructions and a policy approach for necessary laws 
and regulations to improve the credit market environment. The TA team will (i) complete analytic 
studies of credit legislation in key international jurisdictions and provide a study tour to the most 
relevant location; (ii) conduct a national review and consult with formal and informal lenders, 
regulators, and other stakeholders to see what lessons have been learned and what changes 
may encourage formalization, expansion of services, and consumer protection; (iii) assess the 
current legal and regulatory systems to determine which improvements are most appropriate, 
and combine with results from (i) and (ii) to provide a policy approach and drafting instructions 
for legal changes; and (iv) share the proposed results at an international conference to allow 
validation and further input before finalization. 
 
15.  The key outputs for this TA are the following:  
(i)  financial  and  legal  assessment  of  existing  credit  market  circumstances  and 
market conduct, legal and regulatory barriers to responsible delivery of credit, 
particularly to rural households and SMEs, with a technical note as a knowledge 
product; 
(ii)  selective review of legal structures governing credit delivery in key jurisdictions; 
with  analysis  of  a  number  of  areas—both  developed  and  developing—for 
potential lessons, followed by a short and focused study tour to the most relevant 
location; 
(iii)  assessment of and recommendations for legal changes to improve (a) the PRC's 
current legislation, precedents, and legislative proposals for credit definition; (b) 
establishment  of  financial  institutions  providing  credit;  operation  of  such 
institutions; (c) secondary market for trading of loans; and (d) bankruptcy and 
closure of financial institutions providing credit; and 
(iv)  an international conference with key stakeholders to validate recommendations 
in (iii) above for the proposed legal framework for the credit market, and to 
suggest any further revisions. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $525,000 equivalent. The government has 
requested ADB to finance $450,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  TA  will  cover 
remuneration,  travel,  and  per  diem  of  consultants,  as  well  as  training,  workshops,  and 
miscellaneous expenses. The TA proceeds will be disbursed in line with  ADB’s Technical 
Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010).  The  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan  are  in 
Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The  TA  is  expected  to  begin  in  August  2011  and  end  in  January  2013,  with  an 
implementation period of 17 months. The executing agency for the TA is the Legal Affairs 
Department of PBC. Given the wide-ranging issues, other ministries and offices are expected to 
be  consulted,  such  as  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  the  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission, provincial financial markets departments, the State Council Leading Group on 
Poverty Alleviation and Development, and the Civil Affairs Ministry. The executing agency will 
provide office space, counterpart staff, transportation, logistical and travel arrangements to the 
consultants, and will arrange meetings with relevant agencies and organizations. 
 
18.  The  consultants—one  international  (4  person-months)  and  one  national  (9  person-
months)—will be individually selected and engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) and arrangements satisfactory

5 
to ADB for the engagement of national consultants. Equipment (one computer and software, a 
high-speed internet connection, and a printer with scanner) will be procured in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and remain with the 
executing agency at the end of the TA period. The outline terms of reference for consultants is 
in Appendix 3.  
 
19.  The TA team, along with the executing agency, will conduct and document a start-up 
national conference with key stakeholders to discuss the status of the PRC's credit market, the 
results of previous pilots, issues, legal and regulatory constraints, lessons learned, and policy 
issues. Further research and interviews on the domestic credit market structure and operations 
will result in a report and technical note knowledge product for wider reading. The countries 
most likely to offer useful background on the legal framework and regulatory options will be 
determined  and  their  markets  and  lessons  assessed  in  a  detailed  study.  A  policy  note 
knowledge product will accompany this second report. Based on the report and dialogue with 
the executing agency, a study tour will be undertaken to assess experiences of modern credit 
legislation and enforcement that are particularly relevant to the PRC.  Alongside these activities 
the TA team will collect data and assess the status of current PRC legislation, regulation, 
judiciary decisions, and other determinations governing credit. Findings will be synthesized in a 
third and final report with specific recommendations for legal changes and reform—including 
laws that need amending or drafting, drafting instructions, and an overall policy approach. A 
policy note will also be produced as a knowledge product. The PRC stakeholders' review of all 
material will be followed by an international conference to review, comment on, and suggest 
improvements and implementation of recommendations. 
 
20.  In addition to the main outputs, the consultants will submit to ADB and the executing 
agency (i) an inception report two weeks after commencement of services; (ii) interim progress 
reports at appropriate stages during TA implementation; (iii) the draft final report before the 
conclusion of the contract; and (iv) revised final report two weeks after receiving and taking into 
account the comments of, and feedback from, the executing agency, other stakeholders, and 
ADB. All reports will be submitted in English and Chinese.  
 
21.  The executing agency and ADB administration missions will regularly monitor and report 
on major project activities. Consultants’ reports will be presented in workshops and seminars 
organized for the validation of findings. Reports will be made available on ADB websites in 
English and Chinese, if appropriate, and published whenever warranted. The three knowledge 
products will be made available to the public after executing agency clearance. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Developing a Legal System for the Credit 
Market, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  The  consultants—one  international  (4  person-months)  and  one  national  (9  person-
months)—will be individually selected and engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) 
and arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of national consultants. Equipment 
(one computer and software, a high-speed internet connection, and a printer with scanner) will 
be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time) and remain with the executing agency at the end of the technical assistance (TA) period. 
The international consultant (financial credit law expert) will report to the senior legal analysis 
and drafting specialist, who acts as the team leader. Consultants will be required to provide 
deliverables  consistent  with  the  design  and  monitoring  framework  activities,  outputs,  and 
delivery dates. Reports are to be of high quality and produced in English, with copies in Chinese 
also produced by the report delivery dates.

A.  International Consultant 
 
1.  Financial Credit Law Expert (4 person-months) 
 
2.  Qualifications. The expert will have suitable tertiary qualifications in law and related 
research, specializing in legal structures and operations of the finance sector, with a particular 
focus on credit. The expert will have at least 15 years of experience assessing and suggesting 
improvements  to  finance  sector  regulations,  particularly  the  issues  of  credit  definition, 
development, delivery, exit, and supervision. The expert will have access to suitable legal 
documents, regulatory information, and court findings to help ensure completion of TA outputs 
on the international example cases, and have clear knowledge of and contacts within the 
current structure and operations of financial regulators to set up and manage the study tour. The 
expert  will  have  strong  English  language  skills,  and  be  comfortable  working  in  civil  code 
jurisdictions. Experience in Asia, and particularly in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), will 
be an advantage. 
 
3.  Tasks. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Work with the PBC and the team leader at the outset to define credit for the 
purposes of legislation in a way that is suitable to the PRC financial system and 
internationally, helps with market segregation and governance (including formal 
and informal), and delineates the TA task more completely. 
(ii)  Using the results from task (i), work with the team leader to help set up an 
inventory of relevant finance sector laws, regulations, and judicial findings, and 
suggest ways to categorize the inventory and define strengths and weaknesses 
of the existing framework.

(iii)  Using information provided by the People’s Bank of China and the team leader, 
research and provide information on the policy, legal, regulatory, and supervisory 
systems  for  credit  delivery  in  selected  international  jurisdictions.  These  may 
include Australia, Bangladesh; Germany; Hong Kong, China; Japan; the Republic 
of Korea; the United Kingdom; the United States; Taipei,China. Also consider 
emerging  standards  from  the  Bank  for  International  Settlements  and  the 
European Union, including examples of good practice materials. Draft a paper 
with  summaries  for  each  country,  and  lessons  and  information  that  are 
particularly useful to the PRC at this juncture. Also draft a policy note as a 
knowledge product and work with ADB on inclusion of this as a part of the 
knowledge product and services series. 
(iv)  Arrange and manage the meetings and schedule for the study tour to the most 
relevant location. 
(v)  Participate in team discussions and both seminars, and in construction of the 
final reports to help ensure international good practice is taken into account. 
(vi)  Perform quality control on the final English version of all reports. 
 
B.  National Consultant 
 
1.  Senior Legal Analysis and Drafting Specialist and Team Leader (9 person- 
    months) 
 
4.  Qualifications.  The  specialist  will  have  suitable  national  qualifications  in  law, 
specializing in finance sector issues and with a particular focus on credit. The expert will have at 
least 8 years of experience handling finance sector law and regulations, particularly the issues 
of credit definition, development, delivery, exit, and supervision. The expert will have access to 
suitable legal documents, regulatory information, and court findings to help ensure completion of 
TA  outputs,  and  have  clear  knowledge  of  and  contacts  within  the  current  structure  and 
operations  of  financial  regulators.  The  expert  must  be  very  comfortable  working  with 
international experts and in managing field researchers for reviews of issues as needed. The 
expert will have strong Chinese language skills, and be comfortable working in drafting for the 
PRC. The consultant must have good skills in English. 
 
5.  Tasks. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Manage overall TA implementation and quality, and ensure timely completion of 
the study tour, conferences and reports as per the TA design and monitoring 
framework.  
(ii)  Work with the PBC and the international consultant at the outset to define credit 
in a way that is suitable to the PRC financial system and internationally, helps 
with market segregation and governance (including formal and informal), and 
delineates the TA task more completely. 
(iii)  Set up an inventory of relevant financial sector laws, regulations, and judicial 
findings, categorize the inventory, and define strengths and weaknesses of the 
existing credit framework along with suggestions for changes. Draft a policy note 
for inclusion in ADB's knowledge product series. 
(iv)  Using information provided by the People’s Bank of China and the stakeholders 
at the national conference, lay out issues in the current framework, define a 
suitable  revised  legal  and  institutional  structure  that  allows  for  growth  of 
institutions providing credit, list successful pilots that need to be incorporated 
formally in the legal framework, suggest how to address potential risks, and 
areas requiring further research or information.

Appendix 3  11 
 
(v)  Arrange  and  manage  the  meetings  and  schedule  for  the  national  and 
international conferences. 
(vi)  Manage team discussions, ongoing stakeholder dialogue, and construction of the 
final reports to help ensure international good practice is taken into account. 
(vii)  Perform quality control on the final Chinese version of all reports. 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.
